div.head: EXT. PHOENIX, ARIZONA - DAY - HELICOPTER SHOT
div.stage: Above Midtown section of the city. It is early afternoon, a hot mid-summer day. The city is sun-blanched white and its drifted-up noises are muted in their own echoes. We fly low, heading in a downtown direction, passing over traffic-clogged streets, parking lots, white business buildings, neatly patterned residential districts. As we approach downtown section, the character of the city begins to change. It is darker and shabby with age and industry. We see railroad tracks, smokestacks, wholesale fruit-and-vegetable markets, old municipal buildings, empty lots. The very geography seems to give us a climate of nefariousness, of back-doorness, dark and shadowy. And secret.

We fly lower and faster now, as if seeking out a specific location. A skinny, high old hotel comes into view. On its exposed brick side great painted letters advertise "Transients - Low Weekly Rates - Radio in Every Room." We pause long enough to establish the shoddy character of this hotel... Its open, curtainless windows, its silent resigned look so characteristic of such hole-and-corner hotels. We move forward with purposefulness toward a certain window. The sash is raised as high as it can go, but the shade is pulled down to three or four inches of the inside sill, as if the occupants of the room within wanted privacy but needed air. We are close now, so that only the lower half of the window frame is in shot. No sounds come from within the room. Suddenly, we tip downward, go to the narrow space between shade and sill, peep into the room.

A young woman is stretched out on the mussed bed. She wears a full slip, stockings, no shoes. She lies in and attitude of physical relaxation, but her face, seen in the dimness of the room, betrays a certain inner-tension, worrisome conflicts. She is Mary CRANE, an attractive girl nearing the end of her twenties and her rope.
A man stands beside the bed, only the lower half of his figure visible. We hold on this tableau for a long moment, then start forward. As we pass under the window shade,
CUT TO:

div.head: INT. HOTEL ROOM - (DAY)
div.stage: A small room, a slow fan buzzing on a shelf above the narrow bed. A card of hotel rules is pasted on the mirror above the bureau. An unopened suitcase and a woman's large, straw open-top handbag are on the bureau. On the table beside the bed there are a container of Coca-Cola and an unwrapped, untouched egg-salad sandwich. There is no radio.

The man standing by the bed, wearing only trousers, T-shirt and sox, is Sam LOOMIS, a good-looking, sensual shirt man with warm humorous eyes and a compelling smile. He is blotting his neck and face with a thin towel, and is staring down at Mary, a small sweet smile playing about his mouth. Mary keep her face turned away from him. After a moment, Sam drops the towel, sits on the bed, leans over and takes Mary into his arms, kisses her long and warmly, holds her with a firm possessiveness. The kiss is disturbed and finally interrupted by the buzzing closeness of an inconsiderate fly. Sam smiles, pulls away enough to allow Mary to relax again against the pillow. He studies her, frowns at her unresponsiveness, then speaks in a low, intimate, playful voice.

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: Never did eat your lunch, did you.

div.stage: Mary looks at his smile, has to respond, pulls him to her, kisses him. Then, and without breaking the kiss, she swings her legs over the side of the bed, toe-searches around, finds her shoes, slips her feet into searches them. And finally pulls away and sits up.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: I better get back to the office. These extended lunch hours give my boss excess acid.

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: Call your boss and tell him you're taking the rest of the afternoon off. It's Friday anyway... and hot.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: What do I do with my free afternoon, walk you to the airport?

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: We could laze around here a while longer.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Checking out time is three P.M. Hotels of this sort aren't interested in you when you come in, but when your time's up...
Sam, I hate having to be with you in a place like this.

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: I've heard of married couples who deliberately spend occasional nights in cheap hotels. They say it...

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: When you're married you can do a lot of things deliberately.

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: You sure talk like a girl who's been married.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Sam

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: I'm sorry, Mary.
My old Dad used to say 'when you can't change a situation, laugh at it.' Nothing ridicules a thing like laughing at it.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: I've lost my girlish laughter.

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: The only girlish thing you have lost.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Sam. This is the last time.

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: This! Meeting you in secret so we can be... secretive! You come down here on business trips and we steal lunch hours and... I wish you wouldn't even come.

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: Okay. What do we do instead, write each other lurid love letters?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: I haven't time to argue. I'm a working girl.

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: And I'm a working man! We're a regular working-class tragedy!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: It is tragic! Or it will be... if we go on meeting in shabby hotels whenever you can find a tax-deductible excuse for flying down deductible here...

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: You can't laugh at it, huh?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Can you?

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: Sure. It's like laughing through a broken jaw, but...

div.stage: He breaks off, his cheeriness dissolved, goes to the window, tries to raise the shade. It sticks. He pulls at it. It comes down entirely, and the hot sun glares into the room, revealing it in all its shabbiness and sordidness as if corroborating Mary's words and attitude. Sam kicks at the fallen shade, laughs in frustration, grabs on to his humor again.

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: And besides, when you say I make tax-deductible excuses you make me out a criminal.

div.stage: Marion exits a commercial building. Her demeanor is rushed. She glances around nervously and walks quickly to her parked car.
She gets in, starts the engine, and pulls out into light traffic.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: You couldn't be a criminal if you committed a major crime.

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: I wish I were. Not an active criminal but... a nice guy with the conscience of a criminal.
Next best thing to no conscience at all.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: I have to go, Sam.

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: I can come down next week.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: Not even just to see you, to have lunch... in public?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: We can see each other, we can even have dinner... but respectably, in my house with my mother's picture on the mantel and my sister helping me broil a big steak for three!

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: And after the steak... do we send Sister to the movies and turn Mama's picture to the wall?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Sam! No!

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: All right.

div.stage: She stares at him, surprised at his willingness to continue the affair on her terms, as girls are so often surprised when they discover men will continue to want them even after the sexual bait has been pulled in. Sam smiles reassuringly, places his hands gently on her arms, speaks with gentle and simple sincerity.

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: Mary, whenever it's possible, tax-deductible or not, I want to see deductible you. And under any conditions.
Even respectability.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: You make respectability sound... disrespectful.

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: I'm all for it! It requires patience and temperance and a lot of sweating-out... otherwise, though, it's only hard work.
But if I can see you, touch you even as simply as this... I won't mind.

div.stage: He moves away and again the weight of his pain and problems crushes away his good humor. There is a quiet moment.

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: I'm fed up with sweating for people who aren't there. I sweat to pay off my father's debts... and he's in his grave... I sweat to pay my ex-wife alimony, and she's living on the other side of the world somewhere.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: I pay, too. They also pay who meet in hotel rooms.

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: A couple of years and the debts will be paid off. And if she ever remarries, the alimony stops... and then...

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: I haven't even been married once yet!

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: Yeah, but when you do... you'll swing.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Sam, let's go get married.

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: And live with me in a storeroom behind a hardware store in Fairvale. We'll have a lot of laughs. When I send my ex-wife her money, you can lick the stamps.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: I'll lick the stamps.

div.stage: He looks at her, long, pulls her close, kisses her lightly, looks out the window and stares at the wide sky.

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: You know what I'd like? A clear, empty sky... and a plane, and us in it... and somewhere a private island for sale, where we can run around without our... shoes on. And the wherewithal to buy what I'd like.
Mary, you want to cut this off, go out and find yourself someone available.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: I'm thinking of it.

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: How can you even think a thing like that!

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Don't miss your plane.

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: Hey, we can leave together can't we?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: I'm late... and you have to put your shoes on.

div.stage: Mary goes out quickly, closing door behind her. As Sam stares down at his shoeless feet,
DISSOLVE TO:

div.head: EXT. DOWNTOWN STREET - (DAY) - HIGH ANGLE
div.stage: Shooting down at hotel entrance. Mary comes out, walks quickly to a parked cab, gets in. The cab zooms up the awful street.
DISSOLVE TO:

div.head: EXT. LOWERY REAL ESTATE OFFICE - (DAY)
div.stage: A small, moderately successful office off the main street. A cab pulls up at the curb. We see Mary get out of cab, pay driver, cross pavement to the office door.

div.head: INT. OUTER OFFICE - (DAY)
div.stage: Mary enters office, crosses to her desk, sits down, rubs her temples, finally looks over at Caroline, a girl in the last of her teens

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Isn't Mr. Lowery back from lunch?

sp.speaker: Caroline
sp.p: He's lunching with the man who's buying the Harris Street property, you know, that oil lease man... so that's why he's late.
You getting a headache?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: It'll pass. Headaches are like resolutions... you forget them soon as they stop hurting.

sp.speaker: Caroline
sp.p: You got aspirins? I have something... not aspirins, but my mother's doctor gave these to me the day of my wedding.
Teddy was furious when he found out I'd taken tranquilizers!

div.stage: She rises, starts for Mary's desk, pills in hand.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Were there any calls?

sp.speaker: Caroline
sp.p: Teddy called. Me... And my mother called to see if Teddy called. Oh, and your sister called to say she's going to Tucson to do some buying and she'll be gone the whole weekend and...

div.stage: She breaks off, distracted by the sound of the door opening. Mr. Lowery and his oil-lease client, Tom Cassidy, enter the office. Lowery is a pleasant, worried-faced man, big and a trifle pompous. Cassidy is loud and a bit drunk. He is gross, exuding pitiful vulgarity.

sp.speaker: Cassidy
sp.p: Wow! Hot as fresh milk! You girls should get your boss to air-condition you up. He can afford it today.

div.stage: Lowery flashes an embarrassed smile at Mary, tries to lead Cassidy toward the private office.

sp.speaker: Lowery
sp.p: Mary, will you get those copies of the deed ready for Mr. Cassidy.

div.stage: Cassidy pauses beside Mary's desk, hooks a haunch onto the desktop, smiles a wet smile at Mary.

sp.speaker: Cassidy
sp.p: Tomorrow's the day! My sweet little girl... Not you, my daughter! A baby, and tomorrow she stands up there and gets her sweet self married away from me!
I want you to look at my baby. Eighteen years old... and she's never had an unhappy day in any one of those years!

div.stage: Mary glances, cannot bring herself to smile or make a remark, continues sorting out the deed copies, tries to ignore the man's closeness.

sp.speaker: Lowery
sp.p: Come on, Tom, my office is air-conditioned.

sp.speaker: Cassidy
sp.p: You know what I do with unhappiness? I buy it off! You unhappy?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p: Not inordinately.

sp.speaker: Cassidy
sp.p: I'm buying this house for my baby's wedding present. Forty thousand dollars, cash! Now that ain't buying happiness, that's buying off unhappiness! That penniless punk she's marryin'... Probably a good kid... it's just that I hate him.
Yup! Forty thousand, says here... Casharoonie!

div.stage: He takes two bundles of new $100 bills from his pocket and throws them onto the desk under Mary's nose. Caroline's eyes go wide. Cassidy leans close, flicks through the bills, laughs.

sp.speaker: Cassidy
sp.p: I never carry more than I can afford to lose!
Count 'em!

sp.speaker: Lowery
sp.p: Tom... cash transactions of this size! Most irregular...

sp.speaker: Cassidy
sp.p: So what? It's my private money! And now it's yours.

sp.speaker: Caroline
sp.p: I declare!

sp.speaker: Cassidy
sp.p: I don't! That's how I'm able to keep it!

sp.speaker: Lowery
sp.p: Suppose we just put this in the safe and then Monday morning when you're feeling good...

sp.speaker: Cassidy
sp.p: Speakin' of feeling good, where's that bottle you said you had in your desk... Oops! Usually I can keep my mouth shut!

div.stage: He rises, reels toward Lowery's office, pauses, turns, speaks to Mary.

sp.speaker: Cassidy
sp.p: Honest. I can keep any private transaction a secret... any pri....
Lowery! I'm dyin' of thirstaroonie!

div.stage: Lowery starts after him, pauses, turns to Mary. Cassidy has gone into Lowery's office.

sp.speaker: Lowery
sp.p: I don't even want it in the office over the weekend. Put it in the safe deposit box, at the bank, Mary. And we'll get him to give us a check on Monday - instead.

div.stage: He hurries off. When the men are gone and the door is closed, Caroline picks up a bundle and smiles at it.

sp.speaker: Caroline
sp.p: He was flirting with you. I guess he noticed my wedding ring.

div.stage: Mary puts one bundle into a large envelope and takes the other from Caroline. She puts the envelope in her handbag, picks up the remaining deed copies, goes to the private office door, knocks, starts to open it as...

sp.speaker: Lowery
sp.p: Come in.
